siteConfig.metaDescription: Practical guidance for getting the most from Claude AI
siteConfig.welcomeSubtitle: Getting started with AI at AMD Group
siteConfig.industry: Construction and engineering — MEP building services
siteConfig.sensitiveDataDescription: commercial project data, contract values, client financial information, and building specifications

frameworkExamples.1: If AMD Group were a person, they would be a seasoned engineer with over fifty years on the job — technically precise, safety-conscious, and quietly proud of the work. They talk about sustainability with genuine conviction rather than corporate obligation, and they let their track record (repeat business from Lloyds, Wates, HMCTS) speak louder than any sales pitch. There is a family warmth beneath the professional exterior — the kind of company where apprentices become directors.
frameworkExamples.2:
Professional and technically assured — We are precise, knowledgeable, and confident in our technical expertise across M&E disciplines. We are not jargon-heavy for its own sake or dismissive of non-technical stakeholders. Sounds like: 'Our design team specified a variable refrigerant flow system to balance energy efficiency with the building's cooling demand profile.'

Safety-rigorous — We are thorough, evidence-based, and uncompromising on compliance. We are not bureaucratic for its own sake or dismissive of safety as box-ticking. Sounds like: 'Every project begins with a comprehensive RAMS review — because safe delivery is the foundation, not an afterthought.'

Collaboration-focused — We are partnership-minded, relationship-driven, and invested in repeat business. We are not transactional, one-project-and-gone, or adversarial with principal contractors. Sounds like: 'We've worked with Wates across multiple projects because we deliver what we promise — and they know our team by name.'

Sustainability-committed — We are genuinely invested in low-carbon outcomes, not just compliance. We are not greenwashing or treating sustainability as a marketing exercise. Sounds like: 'Our in-house design team models energy lifecycle costs from day one — heat pumps, photovoltaics, and BMS integration are standard practice, not optional extras.'
frameworkExamples.3: Primary: principal contractors, facilities managers, and client-side project managers who need a reliable MEP subcontractor. They want on-time, on-budget delivery, demonstrable safety compliance, and technical depth across mechanical, electrical, and public health disciplines. Secondary: potential employees — apprentices and experienced engineers looking for career progression and stability in a family-founded, nationwide business.
frameworkExamples.4: Pillar 1: Over fifty years of proven MEP experience, from a family-founded business to a nationwide group. Pillar 2: In-house design-and-build capability that reduces coordination overhead and delivers better outcomes. Pillar 3: Genuine commitment to sustainable, low-carbon MEP solutions — heat pumps, photovoltaics, energy lifecycle modelling. Pillar 4: Nationwide coverage from three offices (Dartford, Edinburgh, Sheffield) with a track record of repeat business from major clients.
frameworkExamples.5: Tender response: dial up precision, evidence, and compliance language — accreditation references, project values, named client testimonials. Internal communications: dial up warmth and directness — the family-business culture where people are known by name. Client progress reports: dial up clarity and structure — factual, status-focused, no waffle. Health and safety documentation: dial up rigour and formality — RAMS, method statements, and regulatory compliance demand zero ambiguity.
frameworkExamples.6: UK English throughout. Sentence case for headings. DD/MM/YYYY for dates. £ for currency. Use "MEP" freely — the audience understands it. Spell out acronyms on first use in external documents (e.g. "Building Management Systems (BMS)") but not in internal communications where abbreviations are standard. Contractions acceptable in internal content, avoid in tender responses and formal policies.
frameworkExamples.7: Use "MEP" as the standard abbreviation for mechanical, electrical, and plumbing services. Use "design and build" (not "design-build" or "D&B"). Use "facilities management" (not "FM") in external content; "FM" is acceptable internally. Refer to "principal contractors" (not "main contractors" or "GCs"). Use "accreditations" when referring to Gas Safe, NICEIC, CHAS, etc. — not "certifications" (which implies personal qualifications). Avoid "M&E" — AMD Group uses "MEP" consistently to include public health services.

brandVoice.headStartContent: Based on a review of the AMD Group website, here are the core brand characteristics identified: a mission-driven MEP services provider with over fifty years of experience, positioning sustainable building services as central to achieving net zero. The tone is professional and technically confident, backed by named project evidence and client testimonials rather than generic claims. Key terminology includes MEP, design and build, BMS, ASHP, and LTHW — technical acronyms used freely, reflecting deep industry expertise.

examples.title: PQQ and tender response preparation
examples.description: A skill that searches your library of previous PQQ submissions, finds the closest matching answers for each new question, and drafts a response adapted to the specific tender requirements. Sonia's team currently estimates 70% of PQQ content is reusable across applications — this skill automates the retrieval and adaptation, leaving the team to verify accuracy and add project-specific detail.

examples.title: Weekly client progress report
examples.description: A skill that gathers information from project drawings, site notes, and programme schedules, then produces a structured progress report covering completed work, delays, and next-week plans in AMD Group's standard template. The project manager reviews and adjusts before sending to the client. The intelligence is in the skill; your effort is limited to triggering it and providing the data.

examples.title: Compliance certification tracking
examples.description: A skill that maintains a register of AMD Group's accreditations and certifications — Gas Safe, NICEIC, CHAS, Constructionline, Safe Contractor, and others — with their renewal dates. Run monthly, it flags anything expiring within 60 days and drafts renewal reminders. Over time, it builds a complete audit trail of renewal actions.

examples.title: O&M manual compilation
examples.description: A skill that gathers technical data sheets, commissioning records, and as-built drawings for a completed project, then compiles them into a structured Operation and Maintenance manual in AMD Group's standard format. The project engineer reviews for accuracy and completeness before handover. Particularly valuable for design-and-build projects where AMD Group controls the full documentation chain.

proposal-writing.title: AMD Group PQQ preparation
proposal-writing.description: AMD Group responds to pre-qualification questionnaires as a core part of winning new work. With an estimated 70% content overlap between submissions, AI can retrieve and adapt previous answers, reducing PQQ preparation time from days to hours per submission. Human review remains essential for accuracy and tender-specific requirements.

contract-review.title: AMD Group contract review
contract-review.description: Your commercial team already uses AI to highlight key clauses and risks in subcontract documents. Scaling this across the team — reviewing terms, flagging unusual conditions, and comparing against AMD Group's standard positions — could significantly reduce the time spent on initial contract analysis whilst ensuring consistent risk identification.

compliance-docs.title: AMD Group policy maintenance
compliance-docs.description: With ISO 9001, Gas Safe, NICEIC, CHAS, and multiple other accreditations, AMD Group maintains an extensive library of policies and compliance documents. AI can generate first drafts of policy updates, cross-reference requirements across standards, and flag inconsistencies — reducing the administrative burden of keeping documentation current across the group.
